column1: Will there be a lethal confrontation between the national military forces, militia, and/or law enforcement personnel of India and the People's Republic of China before 1 July 2022?

China's foreign minister recently stopped in Delhi to help calm the border issue. Tanvi Madan, a Senior Fellow at the Brookings Institution and scholar of China-US-India relations, summarized, “India’s not buying what China’s selling.” His tweet is here: https://twitter.com/tanvi_madan/status/1507353245878034437 To me their persistent inability to agree on a defined border continues to contribute to a volatile relationship, maintaining the possibility of a lethal confrontation before this question closes.
maintaining current forecast

Signal: Russia's invasion of Ukraine is impacting almost everything these days. It is easy for a forecaster to get swept up in the noise. On the other hand, some signals are worth mentioning--North Korea's behaviors, China, Iran, and other threats to US interests. In my recent engagement with the Dehli Policy Group (Indian think-tank) and the below links confirming the same, India specifically is worried the US will lose focus on progress made in the Indo-Pacific. The Quad specifically is a fragile organization as the world watches whether or not it will actually produce action or fall into a mere "all talk" organization like is smaller brother ASEAN. This has been a long narrative to say, I am bumping the probability a couple of percentages higher that China will misbehave on the border with India. There is a higher probability China could use the US distraction with Ukraine to poke India.
maintaining current forecast

there are going to be another round of talks between China-India at the end of the week - i'm still assessing low probability of something occurring - but the outcome of those talks could change my assessment

Extremely doubtful that a lethal confrontation will take place. The previous one benefitted no one, and both countries seem focused on other issues (domestic in India, Taiwan for China).

Interesting, I was initially not expecting Olympics to stoke more angst. Apparently, the Games are not immune from this row: https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2022/02/03/india-skip-2022-beijing-olympics-opening-ceremony-torchbearer/6658366001/

Lowered forecast primarily due to successful talks between both countries. Moreover, goodwill gestures are being made (see website) such as China returning the lost teenager. https://www.scmp.com/news/china/military/article/3164979/china-india-border-pla-hands-teen-indian-army-after-he-went

After the Winter Olympics, it seems like a reasonably opportune time for China to continue to take territory. A good read: https://www.economist.com/asia/2021/11/11/how-the-game-of-go-explains-chinas-aggression-towards-india
maintaining current forecast for now. China building a bridge on the border will likely stimulate a response from India.
Ukraine - Russia - US.

Though post-1962 lethal clashes are rare, the strategic situation is changing. Both sides are building infrastructure and moving more military assets to the region. Both countries’ current leaders are also more interested in projecting military strength than were their recent predecessors. China is also taking note of the possibility that previously non-aligned India is working every more closely with the U.S. and other democratic partners. Intentional hostilities still seem unlikely, but this build up of political, diplomatic, and military tension would seem to make the possibility of a small confrontation increasingly more likely. That said, weather is a factor that limits the likelihood of unintentional confrontations to just a few months a year. I think this is a coin flip — does a situation arise between units or troops — during the limited window of this question — that leads to a fight?

Accidents happen and small things can get out of hand.

Sustain my forecast. However, US-India relations can be a trigger for China so as not to escalate confrontational border or maritime Sino-Indian interactions (https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/19/world/asia/india-china-border.html).
Costs to both parties seem to be extremely high for a confrontation of this nature at this time.

Recent confrontations between the forces have failed to yield measurable results and would not result in strategic advantage unless there is a concerted effort for a massive confrontation. There remains a persistent probability because of the proximity of forces and the possibility of miscalculations from either side that could result in a limited, but lethal, confrontation.
Sustain my forecast at 25%. Military buildup has not decreased on the border, it has been maintained. Moreover, the winter months may prove another opportunity for China to make another attempt.
Lethal events are fairly rare.
chances are there even if low.
Lethal confrontations are rare, but have taken place.
maintaining current forecast

Historically there have not been many lethal confrontations since 1959. Where tensions have been heightened over the past 20 months its unlikely to boil over to a lethal confrontation There will continue to be a fair amount of rhetoric. China is also experiencing economic growth pressures that take up a lot of Xi Jinping's time and energy. As well as his efforts to reunify Taiwan. Where I believe China will not give up the argument over the LAC, based on the above conditions, I don't believe there will be a lethal engagement.
1 fatal confrontation out of 5 since 2012 - corresponding to Xi Jinping assuming control in China. PM Modi assumed control in India in 2014. Base rate is 11%.

Having a little trouble understanding what a border skirmish with India would buy Beijing (or vice versa). Even if the US looked for a way to divide Beijing's attention (concerning East Asia), I'm not sure why India would be complicit unless retriggered by some Pakistan-China relations/development nuance (BRI port development in Gwadar, for example). As others noted, the weather would have to play role in any intentional escalation. With that said, there is always room for misinterpretation or emotions at lower levels, so it will be interesting to see how the next de-escalation talks go.
Think this could happen. Background: https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/03/india-china-border-dispute-unlikely-to-end-anytime-soon-nirupama-rao.html
Between the cold weather in the mountains and that both sides want to avoid another confrontation, I think the probability is low.
Only accidental
Actions appear to be more reinforcement of status quo boundaries than intent to change current conditions.
maintaining current forecast

Tensions are rising, and I concur with the QUAD and SCS impacting China's aggressiveness with India. In 2020, there were 5 clashes (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020–2021_China–India_skirmishes). Only 1 was lethal.
While India and the PRC share a long, contested border, the border dispute results in an incursion only once every few years and only twice in 40 years has resulted in fatalities.
India - China relations have deteriorated as a result of Chinese aggression on the Himalayan border that has already produced fatalities in the last decade.
Increasing border tensions indicate risk of further miscalculation. However, these will likely be of limited scope because of the unwillingness of both sides to escalate.

China has becoming increasingly aggressive, but tends to keep its actions short of official conflict. Tensions are high and provocation at the disputed border seems possible if not probable. That being said, the two countries likely want to avoid the beginnings of any interactions that could lead to longterm conflict on their borders.

China and India tensions will remain high but the likelihood of lethal conflict is relatively low due to China's "first explicit admission" that its soldiers were killed in the last major conflict (https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/19/world/asia/china-india-clash.html?searchResultPosition=18)

between May 2020 and January 21 there have been 5 documented clashes between India and PRC; 4 of those 5 occurred prior to July in their respective year (2x January, 1x May, 1x June); 1 of those clashes (june 2020) has confirmed deaths - the rest of injuries.

China and India have too many other issues including Communist Party meeting later this year as well as Economic and election issues in India. More likely problems could come in later part of 2022.

Like a mirror game of chess - sooner or later there is going to be blood...

The relevant universe of cases for me is two - 2020 and 2021 - not the full range of years that this hasn't happened. Nothing fundamental has changed since 2020, though both countries are getting more nationalistic and less risk averse. Though they were able to avoid a confrontation this past year at least some of that is luck.
Tensions are longstanding but rarely result in fatalities (or anything more than skirmishes)

There is a history of ongoing conflict with lethal clashes between the 2 countries over the border. Currently there is an accord in place to help minimize threat of dispute over one aspect of the border, but the risk for conflict remains high. Economic impact from Covid, relations between India-China-Pakistan and India-US deepening alliances are all considerations that could increase tensions and potential for conflict. However, other factors such as the implementation approach taken for some of the proposed US policies for its India relations could help to minimize the potential threat. With a history of conflict and tense political / economic issues on one hand but the Accord holding since early 2021 (i.e. for approx 8 months) on the other hand, it is more than 0% chance but possibly less than a 50% chance for another lethal confrontation to occur in the remaining 8 months.

I think both India and China have learned from the incidents on the Indian / Pakistani border and will be more careful on this border. However, if exercises are conducted too close to the border an incident resulting in a fatality may indeed happen.
Two large nations and an undisputed border. Have been non-lethal in the past, but the recent flare-up that cost lives mean that it could happen again, as neither can afford to lose face.
There have already been lethal clashes, and with tensions continuing, it is likely there will be opportunity for more lethal clashes in this time frame.
No lethal incidents since mid-2020.
It's already happened recently and no de-escalation efforts on either side

China Bhutan negotiations adds a new dimension. Focus in the near term till mid 2022 likely to be infrastructure build up by both sides. Effect of winter on deployed troops and equipment will be a factor.

India , under the govt of Modi has made it very clear to China that any transgression of its borders will not be ignored like under the previous congress govts. China wants more territory but not at any cost. the price will be too high to pay
The forces are disengaging. But not demobilising. Which means there could be an unexpected flash point.
Sources: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020–2021_China–India_skirmishes https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sino-Indian_border_dispute#Dispute_resolution_mechanism
Cross-border activity will accelerate in Spring 2022

So this is clearly brought up by the 2020 confrontation where 20 Indian troops were killed at their Himalayan border. Well, that was the first conflict of the same type in 45 years. By no means should that be a 'well, it won't happen for another 45!' but it's definitely something to consider that these confrontations are few and far between, unlike other nations which regularly scrap. I'd also consider the status of both countries. They both know how it could escalate and what the consequences are, I really doubt they'll ever want a repeat.
Not likely but here is potential.
Neither side wants a lethal engagement but a small chance that things could get out of control briefly.

So the CCP party congress will be in October 2022 where Xi Jinping is expected to break precedent by 'being re-elected for a 3rd term'. Sabre rattling before that date will be required, and coming to blows with India will be much lower-key than more aggressive action in Taiwanese air space. I still think risking blatant confrontation would be atypical given the energy and COVID concerns that China is dealing with right now.
Are forecasters (3% prob) underestimating the risk of accidental casualties or that there is little risk that the conflict worsen?

Why does this question raise its head about every six months? Perhaps because due to a disputed border with an ever increasing aggressive and more powerful country flexing its muscles. Reports suggest that 50,000 and associated weaponry has been collected around the LAC and the current talks have failed where the Chinese have accused the Indian side of unreasonable and unrealistic demands whereas the Indians accused the Chinese of not providing any forward-looking proposals. Troops are in close proximity in a 3500 km long border. The Chinese will not move back from their position in April 2020 per the Indian demands with giving the Indians, in their view having no option to manning the hostile border with a continuous situation. India is the only country with a disputed land border with China which makes diplomatic efforts complicated and possibly India left to its own devices, internationally. China and India have continued to build up military infrastructure along the border with observation towers and forward troop bases. The result being a congested area competing for strategic territorial advantage that increases the potential of military escalation. Given the growth of Chinese economic and by extension military power (possibly wanting to divert from the Taiwan issues with the US) and the Indians weakened by the economic debilitating effect of Covid, this potential flashpoint is a perennial (or at least semi-annual). I wait for the question to arise again 6 months.

There is always a possibility, especially as there are disputed borders and weird things can happen out there in the remote regions. But it happening out of some deliberate manoevering seems quite low. Will have keep an eye on border disputes in coming months
Lots of sabre rattling, especially in India.. but unlikely to get to lethal level...

The build up is mostly to divert attention from domestic issues in India Chinese media is not giving that much coverage to it because they do not believe it is such an important thing, this is also typical of China as a way of snubbing India Elections to India's most populous state are coming up and the ruling right wing party will stir up fervor around clashes and have jingoism as one of calling card to attract voters
Status quo has existed for decades; too much economically for both sides to lose. PRC more focused on Taiwan.
#JGS Reminder30

Local politics are not focused on China tensions, doesn’t mean that the military is not doing anything. Covid-19 closed borders and impacted inflow of people. Maybe this reduced tensions temporarily. Curious if during this time period India will continue to ban apps on a periodic basis, will also need to track other additional retaliations between countries.
No casualties for 16 months, most likely none in the next 9 months. If China escalates current situation, likely not until after the Olympics, which leaves 4 months for this to happen.

What's the source of tension? The root cause is an ill-defined, 3,440km (2,100-mile)-long disputed border. Rivers, lakes and snowcaps along the frontier mean the line can shift, bringing soldiers face to face at many points, sparking a confrontation.

While it may not occur by Dec 1st the Chinese are 'tired' of being humiliated by everyone else on their 'block'. They can't punch Western navies (they can but they won't just yet) they can punch India - and EVERYTHING shows that they're ramping up to do just this.
